Title: Verify Medication Prescribing Safety Check for Drug-Allergy Interaction
Preconditions:
• A test patient 'John Doe' exists in the system.
• The patient 'John Doe' has a documented allergy to 'Penicillin'.
• A user account for 'Dr. Sarah Chen' with prescribing privileges exists.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Dr. Sarah Chen. | Input: User: 'sarah.chen', Password: 'securepassword' | Expected: Dr. Sarah is successfully logged in and sees her dashboard.
Step 2: Search for and open the chart of the test patient 'John Doe'. | Input: Patient Name: 'John Doe', DOB: '1970-01-01' | Expected: Patient John Doe's chart is opened. The allergy list clearly displays 'Penicillin'.
Step 3: Navigate to the medication prescribing module and attempt to prescribe 'Amoxicillin' (a penicillin-class antibiotic). | Input: Medication: 'Amoxicillin', Dose: '500mg', Frequency: 'TID' | Expected: A prominent, non-dismissible critical alert appears, stating a severe drug-allergy interaction between Amoxicillin and the patient's Penicillin allergy.
Step 4: Attempt to override the alert without providing a clinical justification. | Input: Click 'Override' or 'Continue' | Expected: The system prevents the prescription from being finalized. A field requiring clinical justification for the override is displayed and is mandatory.
Expected Results:
The system must block the prescription of a medication to which the patient has a known allergy and display a clear, actionable alert.
Verification Criteria:
• The drug-allergy alert is displayed.
• The prescription cannot be signed or sent without a mandatory override justification.
• The event is logged in the audit trail.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Patient: John Doe, DOB: 1970-01-01, Allergy: Penicillin
• Medication: Amoxicillin

Test Environment: Staging environment with integrated drug database and clinical decision support.

Data Cleanup: Remove the draft prescription from the patient's chart.

Title: Verify Audit Trail Completeness for PHI Access by IT Administrator
Preconditions:
• A test patient 'Jane Smith' exists in the system.
• A user account for 'Admin John Smith' with administrative privileges to view patient charts exists.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Admin John Smith. | Input: User: 'john.smith', Password: 'adminpassword' | Expected: Admin John is successfully logged in and sees the administrative dashboard.
Step 2: Using administrative tools, access the chart of patient 'Jane Smith' to simulate a support-related task. Note the exact time of access. | Input: Patient Name: 'Jane Smith', DOB: '1985-05-10', Reason for access: 'Troubleshooting chart display issue.' | Expected: The patient's chart is displayed in a read-only or 'break-the-glass' mode. A record of the access is generated.
Step 3: Navigate to the system's audit log/trail viewer. | Input: N/A | Expected: The audit log interface is displayed.
Step 4: Filter the audit log for events related to patient 'Jane Smith' and user 'john.smith' around the time of access. | Input: Filter by Patient ID, User ID, and Timeframe. | Expected: An audit log entry is found that contains all required elements: User ID ('john.smith'), Patient ID ('Jane Smith'), type of action ('Patient Chart View'), timestamp, source IP address, and reason for access ('Troubleshooting chart display issue.').
Expected Results:
All administrative access to Protected Health Information (PHI) must be logged in the audit trail with sufficient detail to meet HIPAA requirements.
Verification Criteria:
• The audit log entry is created successfully.
• The entry contains the user, patient, action, timestamp, and reason for access.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Patient: Jane Smith, DOB: 1985-05-10
• Admin User: john.smith

Test Environment: Staging environment with full audit logging enabled.

Data Cleanup: No data cleanup required.

Title: End-to-End Critical Lab Alert Workflow Verification
Preconditions:
• A test lab system simulator is available.
• An ICU patient is configured with Nurse Mary as the assigned nurse and Dr. Sarah as the attending physician.
• User accounts for all three personas are active.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Simulate a critical lab result (e.g., Potassium > 6.0 mEq/L) being sent from a test lab system interface for an ICU patient. | Input: HL7 ORU message with patient MRN, critical lab value, and critical flag. | Expected: The EHR ingests the result. A critical alert is generated and immediately pushed to the assigned ICU nurse, Nurse Mary.
Step 2: Log in as Nurse Mary. Verify receipt of the critical alert on her mobile device. | Input: User: 'mary.johnson', Password: 'nursepassword' | Expected: Nurse Mary receives a high-priority, audible/vibrating notification within 60 seconds of the lab result being sent. The alert clearly states the patient's name and the critical value.
Step 3: As Nurse Mary, acknowledge the alert and use the system's communication tool to send a secure message to Dr. Sarah about the critical lab. | Input: Acknowledge alert. Message to Dr. Sarah: 'Critical K+ of 6.2 on John Doe in ICU Bed 4.' | Expected: The alert status updates to 'Acknowledged'. Dr. Sarah receives a high-priority message notification.
Step 4: Log in as Dr. Sarah. Access the patient's chart directly from the message notification. | Input: User: 'sarah.chen', Password: 'securepassword' | Expected: Dr. Sarah is taken directly to the patient's chart, with the critical lab result highlighted. Chart load time is under 3 seconds.
Step 5: As Dr. Sarah, place an immediate STAT order for intervention (e.g., Kayexalate) and document the decision in a progress note. | Input: Order: 'Kayexalate 15g PO STAT'. Note: 'Critical hyperkalemia, STAT order placed.' | Expected: The order is placed and immediately appears on Nurse Mary's task list/eMAR. The note is saved.
Step 6: Log in as Admin John and review the audit trail for the entire workflow. | Input: User: 'john.smith', Password: 'adminpassword' | Expected: The audit trail shows a complete, time-stamped sequence of events: lab result received, alert sent, alert acknowledged by Nurse Mary, message sent, Dr. Sarah's chart access, order placed, and note signed.
Expected Results:
The system facilitates a rapid and auditable response to a critical clinical event.
Verification Criteria:
• Alert is delivered to the correct user in under 60 seconds.
• Data is synchronized in real-time across different user sessions.
• The entire workflow is captured in the audit trail.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• ICU Patient with MRN
• Critical Lab Value (Potassium > 6.0 mEq/L)

Test Environment: Integrated test environment including EHR, CPOE, and a simulated LIS (Lab Information System) interface.

Data Cleanup: Cancel the STAT order and delete the progress note.

Title: Verify Data Integrity and User Notification During System Maintenance
Preconditions:
• User accounts for Dr. Sarah and Admin John are active.
• Admin John has privileges to schedule and perform system maintenance.
Test Steps:
Step 1: As Dr. Sarah, be in the middle of documenting a patient note. Do not sign it. | Input: Patient: 'Jane Smith', Note: 'Patient presents with...', unsaved. | Expected: The note is in an 'in-progress' state.
Step 2: As Admin John, schedule a system maintenance window to begin in 15 minutes and broadcast a notification to all active users. | Input: Maintenance start: T+15 mins, Duration: 30 mins, Message: 'System maintenance starting soon. Please save your work.' | Expected: Dr. Sarah's session displays a banner/popup with the maintenance notification and a countdown timer.
Step 3: As Dr. Sarah, save the note as a draft. Log out. | Input: Click 'Save as Draft'. | Expected: The note is saved successfully. Dr. Sarah is logged out.
Step 4: As Admin John, once the maintenance window begins, perform a graceful system shutdown, apply a mock patch, and restart the system. | Input: Execute shutdown script, run mock patch script, execute startup script. | Expected: The system shuts down without errors, the 'patch' is applied, and the system restarts successfully. Admin dashboard shows all services are online.
Step 5: As Dr. Sarah, log back into the system after the maintenance window is over. | Input: User: 'sarah.chen', Password: 'securepassword' | Expected: Login is successful. System performance is normal.
Step 6: Navigate to the patient chart for 'Jane Smith' and open the draft note. | Input: Patient: 'Jane Smith' | Expected: The draft note created in Step 1 is present and contains all the text entered before the shutdown. Data integrity is maintained.
Expected Results:
The system can undergo planned maintenance without data loss, and users are effectively notified.
Verification Criteria:
• User notifications are displayed correctly.
• In-progress work can be saved before shutdown.
• Data is fully intact after the system is brought back online.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Test Patient 'Jane Smith'

Test Environment: Pre-production environment that mirrors the production setup.

Data Cleanup: Delete the draft note.

Title: Verify Barcode Medication Administration (BCMA) 'Five Rights' Validation
Preconditions:
• A test patient 'John Doe' has an active IV order for 'Vancomycin 1g'.
• A second test patient 'Jane Smith' exists.
• Test barcodes for patients and medications (correct and incorrect) are available.
• Nurse Mary's account is active.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Nurse Mary on a mobile device and navigate to the eMAR for the correct patient, 'John Doe'. | Input: User: 'mary.johnson', Password: 'nursepassword' | Expected: The eMAR for John Doe is displayed. An order for 'Vancomycin 1g IV' is due.
Step 2: Scan the barcode of the WRONG patient's wristband (e.g., patient 'Jane Smith'). | Input: Scan barcode for Jane Smith. | Expected: The system displays a loud, clear error: 'WRONG PATIENT. Scanned patient does not match selected patient.' The workflow is halted.
Step 3: Scan the barcode of the correct patient's wristband ('John Doe'). | Input: Scan barcode for John Doe. | Expected: The system confirms 'Patient Verified' and prompts for the medication scan.
Step 4: Scan the barcode of the WRONG medication (e.g., 'Ciprofloxacin 500mg'). | Input: Scan barcode for Ciprofloxacin. | Expected: The system displays a loud, clear error: 'WRONG MEDICATION. Scanned medication does not match order.' The workflow is halted.
Step 5: Scan the barcode of the correct medication ('Vancomycin') but with the WRONG dose/concentration (e.g., a 500mg vial instead of 1g). | Input: Scan barcode for Vancomycin 500mg. | Expected: The system displays a clear warning: 'WRONG DOSE. Scanned dose does not match ordered dose. Requires 1g.' The workflow is halted.
Step 6: Scan the correct patient, correct medication, and correct dose. | Input: Scan John Doe's wristband, then scan Vancomycin 1g barcode. | Expected: The system validates all checks and moves to the documentation screen, confirming the Five Rights have been electronically verified.
Expected Results:
The BCMA system must prevent medication errors by strictly enforcing the Five Rights of medication administration through barcode validation.
Verification Criteria:
• Wrong patient scan results in a hard stop.
• Wrong medication scan results in a hard stop.
• Wrong dose scan results in a hard stop.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Patient John Doe with order for Vancomycin 1g IV
• Patient Jane Smith
• Barcodes: John Doe wristband, Jane Smith wristband, Vancomycin 1g, Ciprofloxacin 500mg, Vancomycin 500mg

Test Environment: Test environment with a mobile device and a connected barcode scanner.

Data Cleanup: Un-document the medication administration event.

Title: Measure Patient Encounter Performance and Efficiency for Dr. Sarah
Preconditions:
• A 'Complex Patient' with a large volume of historical data is configured in the system.
• Dr. Sarah's user account is active.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Dr. Sarah. Start a timer. | Input: User: 'sarah.chen', Password: 'securepassword' | Expected: Login is successful.
Step 2: Search for and click to open the chart of a patient with a large medical history (e.g., >10 years of data, >50 problem entries, >100 medications). | Input: Patient: 'Complex Patient' | Expected: The patient's chart, including the summary view, loads completely. Stop the timer and record the time. The time should be less than 3.0 seconds.
Step 3: Start a new timer. Begin the documentation workflow for a routine follow-up visit. | Input: N/A | Expected: The documentation template (e.g., SOAP note) opens.
Step 4: Quickly fill out all sections of the SOAP note, order one new lab test, and refill one existing medication. | Input: Enter text in S, O, A, P fields. Order 'HbA1c'. Refill 'Metformin'. | Expected: All data is entered without system lag. Each action (opening order entry, signing order) completes in under 2 seconds.
Step 5: Sign the note to finalize the encounter documentation. | Input: Click 'Sign Note'. | Expected: The note is signed and the encounter is closed. Stop the timer. The total time for steps 3-5 should be less than 5 minutes.
Expected Results:
The system meets the critical performance success factors for Dr. Sarah's workflow, ensuring efficiency.
Verification Criteria:
• Patient chart load time is measured and recorded.
• Total documentation time is measured and recorded.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Patient record with extensive history (problems, allergies, medications, notes).

Test Environment: Performance test environment with a database size and network latency that mimics production.

Data Cleanup: Delete the newly created note and lab order.

Title: Verify Security Incident Response Log Review for Admin John
Preconditions:
• A 'VIP Patient' is flagged in the system to trigger alerts on access.
• A 'test.nurse' user account exists that should not have access to the VIP patient.
• Admin John's account is configured to receive security alerts.
Test Steps:
Step 1: As a test user (e.g., a nurse from another unit), attempt to access the chart of a high-profile 'VIP' patient, triggering a security alert. | Input: User: 'test.nurse', Patient: 'VIP Patient' | Expected: Access is either denied or requires a 'break-the-glass' override. A high-priority security alert is sent to Admin John.
Step 2: Log in as Admin John and navigate to the security monitoring dashboard. | Input: User: 'john.smith', Password: 'adminpassword' | Expected: The dashboard displays the new high-priority alert for 'Inappropriate PHI Access Attempt'.
Step 3: Click on the alert to drill down into the details. | Input: Click alert. | Expected: A detailed view opens, showing the user ('test.nurse'), patient ('VIP Patient'), timestamp, and nature of the alert.
Step 4: From the alert details, click a link to 'View Full Audit Log for this User'. | Input: Click 'View Audit Log' button. | Expected: The system displays a comprehensive audit log for 'test.nurse' for the last 24 hours. The log is easy to read and filter. The specific access attempt is highlighted.
Step 5: Review the log to check for other suspicious access patterns by this user. | Input: Scroll and filter the log. | Expected: The log provides a clear history of all of the user's actions (logins, patient searches, chart views), enabling a thorough investigation.
Expected Results:
The system provides tools for rapid security incident investigation through real-time alerting and comprehensive, easily accessible audit logs.
Verification Criteria:
• Alert is generated in real-time.
• Admin can access detailed audit logs directly from the alert.
• The audit log contains sufficient detail for an investigation.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• VIP Patient record
• Non-privileged user account 'test.nurse'

Test Environment: Staging environment with security alerting and monitoring enabled.

Data Cleanup: Clear the security alert from the dashboard.

Title: Edge Case - Verify Data Integrity with Simultaneous Patient Record Access
Preconditions:
• A test patient 'John Doe' has at least two active medications (e.g., 'Lisinopril' and 'Metformin').
• User accounts for Dr. Sarah and Nurse Mary exist with privileges to modify medication lists.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Dr. Sarah on one workstation. Log in as Nurse Mary on a second workstation. | Input: User 1: 'sarah.chen', User 2: 'mary.johnson' | Expected: Both users are logged in successfully.
Step 2: Both users search for and open the same patient's chart, 'John Doe', at the same time. | Input: Patient: 'John Doe' | Expected: Both users can view the patient's chart. The system may display a banner indicating that another user is also in the chart, e.g., 'Dr. Sarah Chen is also viewing this chart'.
Step 3: Both users navigate to the medication list. Dr. Sarah attempts to discontinue 'Lisinopril'. At the same time, Nurse Mary attempts to discontinue 'Metformin'. | Input: Dr. Sarah: Discontinue Lisinopril. Nurse Mary: Discontinue Metformin. | Expected: The system should use optimistic or pessimistic locking. The first user to save their change is successful. The second user, upon trying to save, receives a notification that the record has been updated by another user and their view needs to be refreshed.
Step 4: The second user (e.g., Nurse Mary) refreshes her view. | Input: Click 'Refresh' button. | Expected: Nurse Mary's view of the medication list is updated, showing that Lisinopril has been discontinued by Dr. Sarah.
Step 5: Nurse Mary now re-applies her change to discontinue 'Metformin' and saves. | Input: Discontinue Metformin, click 'Save'. | Expected: The change is saved successfully. The final medication list correctly reflects that both Lisinopril and Metformin are discontinued. There is no data corruption or lost update.
Expected Results:
The system must prevent data loss or corruption when multiple users modify the same record concurrently, ensuring data integrity.
Verification Criteria:
• A record locking or refresh mechanism is in place.
• The second user is clearly notified that the record has changed.
• No data from the first user's save is overwritten by the second user's save.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Patient 'John Doe' with active medications Lisinopril and Metformin.

Test Environment: Test environment with two separate workstations/sessions.

Data Cleanup: Re-activate the discontinued medications for the test patient.

Title: Compliance Scenario - HIPAA Audit Trail Verification for Regulatory Inspection
Preconditions:
• User accounts for Dr. Sarah, Nurse Mary, and Admin John exist.
• The admin/compliance role has permissions to run audit reports.
• A test patient 'Jane Smith' exists.
Test Steps:
Step 1: In a separate session, perform a series of actions on a specific patient's chart ('Jane Smith') using different user roles: Dr. Sarah views a lab result, Nurse Mary documents vital signs, and an admin views the chart for support. | Input: Various actions by different users on patient 'Jane Smith'. | Expected: A series of auditable events are created for the patient's record.
Step 2: Log in as Admin John (or a compliance officer role). | Input: User: 'john.smith', Password: 'adminpassword' | Expected: The user is logged in to the administrative dashboard.
Step 3: Navigate to the Audit Reporting or Compliance module. | Input: N/A | Expected: The audit reporting interface is displayed.
Step 4: Generate a report of all activity for patient 'Jane Smith' for today's date. | Input: Report Type: 'Patient Activity', Patient: 'Jane Smith', Start Date: Today, End Date: Today. | Expected: The system generates a report within 2 minutes. The report is displayed on screen and has an option to export to PDF or CSV.
Step 5: Review the generated report for completeness and accuracy. | Input: N/A | Expected: The report contains separate, clear entries for each action performed in Step 1. Each entry includes: a timestamp, the full name/ID of the user who performed the action, the type of action (e.g., 'View Lab', 'Document Vitals'), the patient's name/ID, and the workstation/IP address.
Step 6: Export the report to PDF and verify its contents. | Input: Click 'Export to PDF'. | Expected: A PDF file is generated. The file is well-formatted, readable, and contains all the information verified in the previous step.
Expected Results:
The system can produce a complete, accurate, and human-readable audit report for a specific patient on demand to satisfy regulatory requests.
Verification Criteria:
• The report includes all actions performed on the patient's record.
• Each log entry contains the 'who, what, when, where' of the action.
• The report can be generated and exported in a standard format.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Test Patient 'Jane Smith'

Test Environment: Staging environment with full audit logging enabled.

Data Cleanup: Delete the generated report file.

Title: Verify Efficient Clinical Documentation Using Templates and Smart Phrases
Preconditions:
• Dr. Sarah's user account is configured with access to note templates.
• A 'Diabetes Follow-Up' template has been created.
• Smart phrases '.hba1cplan' and '.counsel[TIME]' have been configured in the system.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Dr. Sarah and open a new note for a patient encounter. | Input: User: 'sarah.chen', Patient: 'John Doe' | Expected: A blank note screen is displayed.
Step 2: Apply a pre-defined note template for a 'Diabetes Follow-Up' visit. | Input: Select Template: 'Diabetes Follow-Up' | Expected: The note is populated with the template structure, including sections for HPI, ROS, Physical Exam, and A/P, with common text and placeholders.
Step 3: In the Assessment/Plan section, type a smart phrase shortcut, such as '.hba1cplan'. | Input: Text: '.hba1cplan' | Expected: The shortcut text is automatically replaced with a full sentence or paragraph, e.g., 'Patient's HbA1c is stable. Will continue current medication regimen. Recheck in 3 months.'
Step 4: Use another smart phrase that includes wildcards or placeholders, such as '.counsel[TIME]'. | Input: Text: '.counsel15' | Expected: The text expands to 'Counseled patient for 15 minutes regarding diet and exercise.' The system correctly inserts the number into the expanded text.
Expected Results:
The system's documentation tools (templates, smart phrases) function correctly and measurably reduce the time and clicks required to complete a clinical note.
Verification Criteria:
• Templates populate the note correctly.
• Smart phrases expand as expected.
• Smart phrases with variables populate correctly.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• Note Templates
• Smart Phrase library

Test Environment: Staging environment.

Data Cleanup: Delete the created note.

Title: Verify Mobile Device Performance and Accessibility for ICU Nurse
Preconditions:
• The ICU test area has multiple Wi-Fi access points to simulate roaming.
• A test patient with active orders, medications, and recent vital signs exists.
• Nurse Mary's account is active.
Test Steps:
Step 1: Log in as Nurse Mary on a hospital-provided tablet from one end of the ICU test area. | Input: User: 'mary.johnson', Password: 'nursepassword' | Expected: Login is successful within 5 seconds. The multi-patient view for the ICU is displayed.
Step 2: From the multi-patient view, tap to open the chart of a critical patient. Start a timer. | Input: Tap on patient 'John Doe'. | Expected: The patient's main chart summary/dashboard loads. Stop the timer. The time should be less than 4 seconds, meeting the <30 second goal for critical info access.
Step 3: Navigate to the patient's Medication Administration Record (eMAR). | Input: Tap 'eMAR' tab. | Expected: The eMAR loads completely within 3 seconds.
Step 4: Walk to the other end of the ICU test area, forcing the device to switch Wi-Fi access points. | Input: Physical movement across the unit. | Expected: The application remains connected and responsive. No session timeout or 'reconnecting' message is displayed.
Step 5: While still at the new location, navigate to the real-time vital signs flowsheet. | Input: Tap 'Flowsheets' tab. | Expected: The flowsheet loads within 3 seconds and displays the most recent data.
Expected Results:
The mobile application provides fast, reliable access to critical patient data and maintains a stable session while roaming within the clinical environment.
Verification Criteria:
• Chart and module load times are within acceptable limits.
• The session is not interrupted by Wi-Fi access point transitions.
Test Data:
Required Data:
• ICU test patient record.

Test Environment: A physical test area mimicking an ICU with enterprise-grade Wi-Fi. A standard hospital tablet device.

Data Cleanup: Log out of the user session.
